text: AstroAngles looks really nice!  I haven't had a chance to play with it yet, but one of the tricky parts of this is how to deal with negative angles, especially ones between 0 and -1 degree.  Assuming "-12:34:56" get broken up into (-12, 34, 56) you don't get the right value with -12 + 34/60 + 56/3600.  At least some libraries handle this by making the sign a separate field, where sign is either +1 or -1.  So -12:34:56 would get broken up into (-1, 12, 34, 56) and -00:00:01 would get broken up into (-1, 0, 0, 1).  Sorry if you've already addressed this...

yeah I have (hopefully) dealth with it if you look inside the `dms2deg` (as an example) I do something roughly like
```d, m, s = dms
fractional = m / 60 + s / 3600
if d < 0
    return d - fractional
else
    return d + fractional
end```
so the parsing will take `"-12:34:56"` -> `(-12, 34, 56)` -> `-12 + sign(-12) * 0.568` -> `-12.568` (didn’t actually do the math but the point still stands)

Specifically for `-0` -> it seems to work!
```julia> parse_dms("-0:0:0")
(-0.0, 0.0, 0.0)

julia> ans |> dms2deg
-0.0```

text:
so the two use-cases I see for this package are

(1) I’m at the REPL and have a specific object I’ve, say, looked up on Simbad and want to do some coordinate math. This user will be typing in strings at the REPL and benefit from the literal string macros
```juila> using AstroAngles, SkyCoords
julia> coord = ICRSCoord(hms"-12:53:365.9", dms"05:33:05.3")```
For this user, the additional complexity required to parse `hms"12"` is much greater than the user just adding two 0s to their string

(2) I have a target list in a csv and want to load them in before doing coordinate math. These users need to have consistent string parsing, but the target list is much more likely to have standardized string representations.

```ICRSCoord(hms"...", "dms"...")```
is as simple as possible

text: Some of the radio astronomy data file formats I work with (and create datasets for) store RA as decimal degrees (i.e. the telescope gives the observed RA as a sexagesimal string and it needs to be stored as decimal degrees).  That's not as bad as one file format that stores degrees, minutes, seconds as a floating point number that is "degrees*10000 + minutes*100 + seconds".  Which is great for humans to read, but terrible for computers :sweat_smile:
